causes: Colonial rivalry between Britain and France
Expansion of British and French territories in North America and India
Austrian desire to recover Silesia from Prussia
Spanish and French opposition to British maritime dominance
events_leading_up_to_war: British and French skirmishes in North America (1754–1755)
Diplomatic Revolution (1756) leading to new alliances
Prussian invasion of Saxony, triggering European hostilities

territorial_changes: France cedes Canada and lands east of the Mississippi to Britain
Spain cedes Florida to Britain in exchange for Havana, Cuba
France cedes Louisiana west of the Mississippi to Spain
Britain gains control of key territories in India and the Caribbean

allies: Native American tribes allied with the French

British_and_Prussian_Alliance.naval_power: Largest navy in the world at the time

French_and_Austrian_Alliance.troops: Approx. 250,000 (including Austrian, Russian, and Spanish forces)
French_and_Austrian_Alliance.naval_power: Significant but outmatched by the British

casualties_and_losses.civilian_losses: Hundreds of thousands due to war-related famine and disease
